warnings_strict_justification: Default warnings are turned on and turned off where not sensible. Pre-commit prevents commits with warnings. This is enforced by Travis, the CI tool.
crypto_published_justification: The SDK uses the OSS requests package, which handles TLS/cryptography internally.
crypto_call_justification: The SDK uses the OSS requests package, which handles TLS/cryptography internally.
crypto_floss_justification: The SDK uses the requests package, which internally calls into an OSS SSL stack by default.
crypto_keylength_justification:
The project does not by itself configure or use cryptography; in particular, the project is not configuring key lengths.

This handled by the requests package, which internally decides which SSL stack to use. See e.g. the changelog entry for 2.24.0, which references how requests chooses the SSL implementation:

https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/community/updates/#id2

The project offers a security guide, which in particular advises and describes how to update the entire environment to get the latest security fixes: https://data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security.html#keep-the-environment-up-to-date

By following these instructions regularly, the latest and most secure version of the requests dependency will be available.

delivery_mitm_justification:
The SDK is delivered either via Pypi or via Github. Both mechanism support HTTPs. It is possible that individual users configure their delivery channel (e.g. the Pip package manager) to use an insecure HTTP connection, but that is not a standard configuration on recent versions of pip and thus out of scope.

https://pypi.org/project/data-attribute-recommendation-sdk/
delivery_unsigned_justification:
Pip - which is the main delivery mechanism - does not enable hash checking by default: https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#hash-checking-mode

If enabled, the mode works by having a local copy of the hashes against which pip will compare the hash of the downloaded component. The local copy of the hashes must be obtained via a separate channel, such as the Pypi.org website. Example: https://pypi.org/project/data-attribute-recommendation-sdk/0.7.1/#copy-hash-modal-b427bf5a-e3ad-4b2e-8b26-aab1e52b5d83

Since this website is reachable via HTTPS and implements a HTTP 301 redirect when accessed via plain non-encrypted HTTP, we can consider this requirement to be fulfilled.

The aspect relating to " without checking for a cryptographic signature." is also satisfied, as the browser verifies the certificate presented by Pypi.org.

There is no wide-spread support for package signing in the Python landscape, which is why we have not implemented dedicated package signing using a maintainer-specific key. See https://dzone.com/articles/package-signing-in-pip-it-works-in-a-roundabout-so
static_analysis_justification: The SDK uses pylint, pep8, mypy and bandit: https://github.com/SAP/data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk/blob/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j:
Yes, the bandit tool: https://github.com/SAP/data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk/blob/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml
Also, the project uses the CodeQL tool provided by Github: https://github.com/SAP/data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk/actions?query=workflow%3ACodeQL
static_analysis_often_justification:
The static analysis via pre-commit is executed for every PR by Travis CI, but not daily. On the developer's machine, the static analysis is executed every commit if they have set up the pre-commit tool according to the instructions provided by the project. 

The CodeQL check runs every week: https://github.com/SAP/data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk/actions?query=workflow%3ACodeQL

Based on the points above and the small code base and attack surface, it is fair to set this requirement to "MET".
dynamic_analysis_justification:
To my knowledge, there are very few dynamic analysis tools available for Python.

We may consider the Hypothesis test framework for Python in the future, if we find a use case where we would benefit.

From the description above: "be an automated test suite with at least 80% branch coverage"

The project currently do not measure branch coverage, but we may consider this.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Project does not have dynamic analysis.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Project does not have dynamic analysis.
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
The project does not by itself configure or use cryptography; in particular, the project is not configuring key lengths.

This handled by the requests package, which internally decides which SSL stack to use. See e.g. the changelog entry for 2.24.0, which references how requests chooses the SSL implementation:

https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/community/updates/#id2

The project offers a security guide, which in particular advises and describes how to update the entire environment to get the latest security fixes: https://data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security.html#keep-the-environment-up-to-date

By following these instructions regularly, the latest and most secure version of the requests dependency will be available.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Project uses travis to execute style checks, code analysis (both via pre-commit) and to run tests (via tox).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
access_continuity_justification:
Several people have access to the repository and can manage issue. Release process is automated and can be triggered by people with write access to repo: https://data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk.readthedocs.io/en/latest/release_process.html

Credentials are stored in safe location and relevant SAP colleagues have access.
documentation_achievements_justification:
Badge will be there after PR is merged:

https://github.com/SAP/data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk
internationalization_justification: Project is an SDK and not intended to be used by end-users. No text sorting is implemented.
sites_password_security_justification: Project websites does not store passwords for authentication of external users. Encryption is handled by Github and other providers such as Coveralls, Readthedocs etc.

Instructions in CHANGELOG.md: https://github.com/SAP/data-attribute-recommendation-python-sdk/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md

Typically, we will provide an upgrade path and not maintain older versions.

name: Orion Context Broker
description:
The Orion Context Broker is an implementation of the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker GE, providing an NGSI interface. Using this interface, clients can do several operations:

Query context information. The Orion Context Broker stores context information updated from applications, so queries are resolved based on that information. Context information consists on entities (e.g. a car) and their attributes (e.g. the speed or location of the car).
Update context information, e.g. send updates of temperature
Get notified when changes on context information take place (e.g. the temperature has changed)
Register context provider applications, e.g. the provider for the temperature sensor within a room

This project is part of FIWARE. For more information check the FIWARE Catalogue entry for Core Context Management.( https://www.fiware.org/developers/catalogue/ )

https://www.fiware.org/developers/catalogue/

build_justification: Dockerhub makes an automatic build of the software (automatizing the same process that is described at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-orion/blob/master/doc/manuals/admin/build_source.md): <https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-orion/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt>.
build_common_tools_justification: Well-known C++ building tools (CMake, etc.) are used for this purpose
build_floss_tools_justification: The building tools are FLOSS https://cmake.org/licensing/
test_justification: Yes, it includes a test suite . https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-orion#testing
test_invocation_justification: Yes. This is documented in the README.md
test_most_justification: Met. Currently coverage of the codebase is  87.1% for lines and 96.1% for functions
test_policy_justification: Yes. The contribution policies at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-orion/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution_guidelines.md says, "PR modifications must pass full regression based on existing test (unit, functional, memory, e2e) in addition to whichever new test added due to the new functionality"
tests_are_added_justification: Tests are added as new functionality is added. This is verified during the pull request code review, ensuring that proper tests are included in the pull request before merging it.
tests_documented_added_justification: Yes, at the contribution policies at https://github.com/telefonicaid/fiware-orion/blob/master/doc/manuals/contribution_guidelines.md.
warnings_justification: The project uses Google’s cpplint (https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint) as linter.
warnings_fixed_justification: In general warnings are addressed. In some cases warnings are disabled for specific cases.
warnings_strict_justification: The settings for the warning tools are generally fairly strict.
know_secure_design_justification: The Orion development team has developers who know how to design secure software
know_common_errors_justification: The Orion development team has developers who know how to design secure software
crypto_published_justification: This application is a microservice which delegates authentication and authorization to other components such as Keyrock or Keystone. These security components use bcrypt to store salted hashed iterated passwords, and https+standard crypto protocols to communicate with users. Orion Context Broker also uses https+standard crypto in its service API, either directly or using some intermediate proxy (such as nginx).
crypto_call_justification: Orion Context Broker (and other libraries used by it, such as libmicrohttpd or libcurl) rely on openssl library, which is a well-known library implementing cryptographic.
crypto_floss_justification: The aforementioned openssl library uses a FLOSS license. https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
crypto_keylength_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by Orion Context Broker and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) allow the usage of such minimum key lengths.
crypto_working_justification: Orion Context Broker doesn’t use any broken cryptographic algorithm.
crypto_pfs_justification: Nothing in the code inhibits or prevents the use of PFS; that is a property of the website's web server.
crypto_random_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by Orion Context Broker and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) use randomized mechanisms.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Orion Context Broker does not cryptographic hashes in any HTTP unsecure endpoint.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
static_analysis_justification: The project uses Google’s cpplint (https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint) for this purpose. This analysis tool is used as part of the default test process used in local development, as well as the continuous integration server
static_analysis_fixed_justification: This is vacuously true, since we've had no reports of vulnerabilities that apply to a deployed system.
static_analysis_often_justification: All commits to GitHub are run through Github Actions, which performs a number of static analysis checks
dynamic_analysis_justification: Dynamic code analysis has been applied using Valgrind tool
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Valgrind is integrated on our regression test process
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No issues were found by dynamic analysis.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: Orion Context Broker doesn’t depend on cryptographic algorithms with known vulnerabilities.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Code implements continuous integration based in GitActions. Each time a new pull request is created, the continuous integration system runs the test on it and it is ready to merge only when all tests pass ok. If a problem is found, feedback is provided via GitHub. In addition, several badgets on top of the master README.md of the project provide information about the build status in the master branch.
discussion_justification: GitHub issue tracker and pull requests support discussion
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No valid private credentials appears in public repositories. When some usernames and/or passwords needs to be used, it is never included in repositories and proper mechanism (e.g. Docker secrets) are used at software building and deployment time.
english_justification: All documentation is in English (and also in Japanese), and the project accepts bug reports and comments in English.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

Automated tests are run with each commit to the code repository using Github actions continuous integration.
The instructions for running the tests can be found in: https://github.com/ging/fiware-cosmos-orion-flink-connector#testing
test_invocation_justification: The instructions for running the tests can be found in: <https://github.com/ging/fiware-cosmos-orion-flink-connector#testing>
test_most_justification: The code uses coverage and coveralls to track test coverage and shows the badge in the main page
test_policy_justification: Yes. The CONTRIBUTING file at: <https://github.com/ging/fiware-cosmos-orion-flink-connector/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md> says, "Please ensure that your contribution passes all tests". Also, the README shows the test coverage, which encourages adding tests as new functionality is added.
tests_are_added_justification: Tests are added as new functionality is added.
tests_documented_added_justification: Yes. The CONTRIBUTING file at <https://github.com/ging/fiware-cosmos-orion-flink-connector/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md> says, "Please ensure that your contribution passes all tests".
warnings_justification:
The set of tools used for examining code quality are listed in CONTRIBUTING.md. 
The project uses eslint is used to look for problems in Javascript. The markdown documentation is scanned with remark and textlint.
warnings_fixed_justification: In general warnings are addressed. In some cases warnings are disabled for specific cases.
warnings_strict_justification: The settings for the warning tools are generally fairly strict.
know_secure_design_justification: @sonsoleslp assumes overall responsibility for this along with the development team.
know_common_errors_justification: @sonsoleslp assumes overall responsibility for this along with the development team.
crypto_published_justification: This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock or Keyrock. These security components use bcrypt to store salted hashed iterated passwords, and https+standard crypto protocols to communicate with users. The software uses bcrypt to store salted hashed iterated passwords, and https+standard crypto protocols to communicate with users.
crypto_call_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components for cryptography.
Uses bcrypt  package for bcrypt, and https implementation built into its web server.
crypto_floss_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components for cryptography. FLOSS cryptography is available in compatible components
such as Keyrock. All required functionality is implemented using FLOSS, including cryptography.
crypto_keylength_justification: This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components for cryptography.
crypto_working_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock. Keyrock uses bcrypt, which is not broken.
The only cryptographic algorithm directly used by the program is bcrypt, which is not broken.
crypto_pfs_justification: Nothing in the code inhibits or prevents the use of PFS; that is a property of the website's web server.
crypto_password_storage_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock. Keyrock uses bcrypt for storing local passwords.
Bcrypt used for storing local passwords.
crypto_random_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock or Keycloak. These security components are using randomized
mechanisms.
The nonce for the salt is created by the bcrypt package; its code shows that it uses OpenSSL to get cryptographically random data for the salt. Other nonces are part of the
https implementation, which are implemented by the web server (not this application).
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Snyk is used for vulnerability search
static_analysis_fixed_justification: This is vacuously true, since we have had no reports of vulnerabilities that apply to a deployed system.
static_analysis_often_justification: All commits to GitHub are run through Github actions, which perform a number of static analysis checks (eslint, hadolint, etc.).
dynamic_analysis_justification: Dynamic code analysis has been applied through unit testing
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The language used is not memory unsafe
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions
that are checked during automated testing.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No issues were found by dynamic analysis.
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock. Keyrock uses bcrypt, which is not broken.

The only cryptography used directly by this application is bcrypt (used for storing passwords as salted iterated hashes). At the time of this writing, no serious breaks are
known in bcrypt. The application also depends on the web server's https configuration, but that is out of scope for this code.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Continuous integration is done with Github actions: <https://github.com/ging/fiware-cosmos-orion-flink-connector/actions>
discussion_justification: GitHub issue tracker and pull requests support discussion
no_leaked_credentials_justification:
No valid private credentials are leaked. Usernames and Passwords may be entered
using Docker secrets and ENVs
english_justification:
All documentation is in English, and the project accepts bug reports and comments in
English.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

interact_justification:

And more at https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec
documentation_interface_justification:
The sidebar https://kubesec.io/ documents the scanners rules
There is also insight into how it's downloaded, used as a cli and ran as a http service, or used hosted at https://v2.kubesec.io/scan
And more at https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec

repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: I'm not sure what this means. Like pre-release/alpha/beta releases before full releases?
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification:
We tag releases and on tag creation the CI runs and creates a release
Also see release account on the GH releases page
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/releases
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.github/workflows/release.yml
release_notes_justification:
Release notes are in the README and releases

https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec#release-notes
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/releases
report_responses_justification: All non-contributor posted issues have been responded to
enhancement_responses_justification: All non-contributor posted issues have been responded to
build_common_tools_justification:
Make & standard go tooling
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/Makefile
goreleaser for releases
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.goreleaser.yml
test_justification:
Unit testing is done using go testing for code and bats for cli regression

https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yml
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/Makefile#L87-L90
warnings_fixed_justification:
All new warnings from linting are met
There are some legacy linting complains like adding some comments that haven't been done though
warnings_strict_justification: We strict fail on security scanning. Might be able to beef up golanglint rules
know_secure_design_justification: 06kellyjac is aware of how to design secure software & our company focuses on security and specifically supply chain security and cloud consulting
crypto_call_justification: For the http server we leave that to the http library. The only other cryptography added is in-toto, this uses the official in-toto libraries and was added to kubesec by the creator of in-toto
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat:
CodeQL and Trivy reporting to the GitHub security dashboard list 0 security advisories
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.github/workflows/security_analysis.yml
static_analysis_justification:
CodeQL and Trivy used
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.github/workflows/security_analysis.yml

Trivy is FLOSS
static_analysis_fixed_justification:
CodeQL and Trivy reporting to the GitHub security dashboard list 0 security advisories, none reported so far
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.github/workflows/security_analysis.yml
static_analysis_often_justification:
CodeQL and Trivy are ran on every PR into master, every push to master, and every day at 6:00am
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/blob/master/.github/workflows/security_analysis.yml
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification:
golang should be pretty memory safe but we're also looking at adding a fuzzer
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/issues/127
general_comments: The documentation could do with some work but I think it's a solid start as is for a CLI tool
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec#getting-help
no_leaked_credentials_justification:
No secrets in the repo found so far.
TODO: add truffle hog or equivalent
https://github.com/controlplaneio/kubesec/issues/129
english_justification: The website and repo are in English.

name: vidgear
description: High-performance cross-platform Video Processing Python framework powerpacked with unique trailblazing features
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/abhiTronix/vidgear/blob/master/contributing.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/abhiTronix/vidgear/blob/master/LICENSE>.

repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
general_comments:
VidGear is a High-Performance Video Processing Python Library that provides an easy-to-use, highly extensible, Multi-Threaded + Asyncio Framework on top of many state-of-the-art specialized libraries like OpenCV, FFmpeg, ZeroMQ, picamera, starlette, pafy, pyscreenshot and python-mss at its backend, and enable us to flexibly exploit their internal parameters and methods, while silently delivering robust error-handling and unparalleled real-time performance.

VidGear primarily focuses on simplicity, and thereby lets programmers and software developers to easily integrate and perform Complex Video Processing Tasks, in just a few lines of code.
